rsbNotes.title: Pr 5
rsbNotes.text: 5:1–23 This passage is best taken as a single unit. While vv. 15–23 are conceivably a distinct composition, the theme is a logical development of what goes before. Wisdom urges us to avoid the life-destroying adulteress and to find sexual and emotional satisfaction in faithfulness to the marriage bond.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 5:15
rsbNotes.text: 5:15 Drink water . . . cistern. The context suggests that this is a metaphor for marital relations with one’s wife.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 5:16
rsbNotes.text: 5:16 springs . . . streams. The imagery suggests the wastefulness of a promiscuous life.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 5:18
rsbNotes.text:
5:18 fountain. Another metaphor for the wife, perhaps indicating the bearing of many children.

wife of your youth. The wife taken when you were young.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 5:19
rsbNotes.text: 5:19 The poetic language of this verse is like that of the Song of Solomon. The imagery of a graceful animal of rare beauty emphasizes physical pleasure as integral to marital relations. See Song 1:2, 3; 4:1–7.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 5:21–23
rsbNotes.text: 5:21–23 Up to this point, the warnings against adultery have not been referred to God’s law. Similar warnings can be found in other wisdom traditions. Now the writer explains that the natural consequences of folly, and especially sexual folly, are punishments ordained by God.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 5:21
rsbNotes.text: 5:21 ponders. Or “takes note of.” Our behavior is under constant scrutiny. The text does not say that every sin is visited with an immediate penalty. Rather, God oversees the created order so that sinners are captured by their own folly (vv. 22, 23).
